Question: Which famous structures, both designed or structurally influenced by Gustave Eiffel?

question: Which famous structures, both designed or structurally influenced by Gustave Eiffel?
retrieved_documents:
The Eiffel Tower is located in Paris, France.
The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889.
The Eiffel Tower is 324 meters tall.
The Eiffel Tower was designed by Gustave Eiffel.
The Eiffel Tower is painted every seven years to prevent it from rusting.
The Eiffel Tower has three levels accessible to the public, with restaurants on the first and second levels.
The Eiffel Tower was the tallest man-made structure in the world until the completion of the Chrysler Building in New York City in 1930.
During the winter, the Eiffel Tower shrinks by about 6 inches (15 cm) due to the cold. The Statue of Liberty is located in New York City, USA.
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States.
The Statue of Liberty was dedicated on October 28, 1886.
The Statue of Liberty is 93 meters tall from the ground to the tip of the torch.
The Statue of Liberty's full name is "Liberty Enlightening the World."
The seven spikes on the Statue of Liberty's crown represent the seven seas and seven continents of the world.
The internal structure of the Statue of Liberty was designed by Gustave Eiffel, who also designed the Eiffel Tower.
The torch of the Statue of Liberty was originally designed to serve as a lighthouse, but the torch was never used for this purpose. The Colosseum is located in Rome, Italy.
The Colosseum was completed in AD 80.
The Colosseum could hold up to 80,000 spectators.
The Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
The Colosseum had a retractable awning, called the "velarium," to protect spectators from the sun and rain.
The Colosseum is elliptical in shape, with a length of 189 meters (620 feet) and a width of 156 meters (512 feet).
The floor of the Colosseum was made of wood and covered with sand to absorb the blood from gladiatorial contests.
The Colosseum is partially ruined due to earthquakes and stone-robbers who used its material for other constructions.
